summary.text_en: Aristarchus was the first known astronomer to propose a complete 'Heliocentric' model of the universe. He boldly hypothesized that a stationary Sun (not the Earth) was at the center, and that the Earth was a planet that rotated on its own axis (explaining day and night) while simultaneously revolving around the Sun.
key_points_en: His book on heliocentrism is lost

story.text_en: Aristarchus's original work on heliocentrism is lost. We only know of it because Archimedes mentioned it in his book, 'The Sand Reckoner'. Archimedes wrote: '[Aristarchus's] hypotheses are that the fixed stars and the Sun remain unmoved, that the Earth revolves about the Sun...' The theory was universally rejected for 1,800 years because it contradicted Aristotelian physics (if the Earth moved, why don't we feel it?) and lacked observable 'stellar parallax' (a shift in star positions).

fun_facts.text_en: His only surviving work is 'On the Sizes and Distances of the Sun and Moon'. He used the geometry of a half-moon (which forms a right-angle triangle with the Earth and Sun) to calculate the Sun's distance. His geometry was perfect, but his measurements were off. He concluded the Sun was 20x bigger than Earth (it's really 109x), but this was enough to convince him the tiny Earth shouldn't be the center.
Copernicus knew of Aristarchus's theory and credited him in the original manuscript of 'De revolutionibus', but the reference was removed before publication.

simple_explanation.text_en: While everyone believed Earth was the center of the universe, Aristarchus was the first person to say, 'Wait, I think we have this backwards. That giant, bright Sun looks a lot more like the boss. What if *we* are moving around *it*?' This idea sounded crazy at the time, as people asked, 'If the Earth is moving, why aren't we all thrown off?' His idea was so advanced it was ignored for 1,800 years until Copernicus.

applications.text_en: His work 'On Sizes and Distances' was the first attempt to use rigorous geometry (instead of philosophy) to measure the solar system, pioneering the field of cosmic distance measurement.

impact.text_en: In antiquity, Aristarchus's heliocentric hypothesis had almost zero impact; it was completely overshadowed by the success of the geocentric model (perfected by Hipparchus and Ptolemy). However, his idea was rediscovered during the Renaissance and provided Copernicus with crucial 'ancient authority', proving his theory was not a new heresy, but a revival of classical wisdom. In this sense, Aristarchus was the 'godfather' of the Scientific Revolution.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Pythagoreans (specifically Philolaus, who had already proposed a moving Earth orbiting a 'Central Fire')

influenced.contribution_en: Hipparchus (who, despite rejecting heliocentrism, used Aristarchus's observational data, like the length of the solar year)
Copernicus (provided the critical ancient precedent and inspiration for his heliocentric model)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Aristarchus was the first person to put the Earth in its proper place in the cosmos, even if the world wasn't ready to listen for nearly 2,000 years.

quiz.question_en: What was the main *scientific* reason the ancient Greeks rejected Aristarchus's heliocentric model?
options_en: It violated Aristotelian physics and they could not observe 'stellar parallax'
Aristarchus miscalculated the size of the Sun
They thought the Sun was a burning rock, not a god
Pythagorean math proved the Earth was the center
quiz.explanation_en: There were two main objections: 1. Physics: If the Earth was moving so fast, why weren't we thrown off? 2. Observation: If the Earth orbits the Sun, nearby stars should 'wobble' back and forth against distant stars over the year (parallax). They could not observe this, so they (incorrectly) concluded the Earth must be stationary.
